abstract.p: We address the problem of farm and parasitic risk profiling in the context of Veterinary Epidemiology. We take advantage of a cross-sectional study carried out in the Campania Region in order to study the spatial distribution of 16 parasites in 121 ovine farms. We propose a tri-level hierarchical Bayesian model, which account for multivariate spatially structured overdispersion, to obtain estimate of posterior classification probabilities, that is for each parasite and farm the probability to belong to the set of the null hypothesis. We explore four decision rules based on either posterior probabilities or posterior means and compare the results in terms of the number of false discoveries/non-discoveries or the rate of false discovery/non-discovery. Our approach proved useful for parasitological risk profiling and we show that decision rules can be easily handled.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: In Veterinary Epidemiology, farm and/or parasite risk profiling has an important role. Let us assume a survey is conducted to screen I farms for the presence of K parasitic diseases. Then, we have a matrix of I × K tests of hypothesis—the null hypothesis being absence of parasitic infection—and we must adjust for multiple testing. In fact, the use of the p values, the so-called per-comparison approach, fails to control the error rate at the desired α level. The control of Family-Wise Error Rate, e.g. via the Bonferroni correction,1 may be a solution, but it is too stringent for the purpose of this kind of surveillance (e.g. see reference [2]). The control of false discovery rate (FDR)3 or false non-discovery rate (FNR) has been proposed as alternative. It has been shown to be more appropriate for our purposes in policy making because our decision is not necessarily invalid if one null hypothesis is erroneously refused.4 FDR is the expected value of the proportion of false positives among all the rejected null hypothesis, while FNR is the expected value of the proportion of false negatives among all the accepted hypothesis. Storey5 restricted the attention to a component of FDR, the positive FDR (pFDR), which, under certain assumptions, can be shown to be a posterior probability. We will follow this Bayesian approach. Hierarchical Bayesian modeling naturally account for multiplicity.6 In this paper, we do not follow some authors’ suggestions to apply multiple testing corrections on posterior probabilities from a hierarchical model (e.g. reference [7]). Instead our approach is similar to Müller et al.8 who presented an application to Genomics data analysis. In a Bayesian framework, adjustment for multiple comparisons is addressed only when non-zero probability for the null hypothesis is assigned and the model includes a hyperparameter that controls the prior probability mass for the null. In this work, we propose a tri-level hierarchical Bayesian model to obtain, for each i-th farm and k-th parasitic disease, posterior classification probabilities, i.e. the posterior probability of the null hypothesis. Once having obtained posterior probabilities, we use them to decide if a farm and/or a parasite is at altered risk or not.9 We explore four decision rules that can be schematically described by a two-by-two table where we define a cut-off on posterior probabilities or on posterior means (rows) and the number or rate of false discoveries/non-discoveries (columns). The results can be summarized, jointly and marginally, by parasites and by farms. The novelty of our approach stands in developing a spatial hierarchical Bayesian tri-level model. The spatial structure is used to borrow strength and improve the estimation of posterior classification probabilities.
We take advantage of a real example in the Campania Region (Italy) in order to study the spatial distribution of 16 parasitic infections in 121 ovine farms.

In Section 2, we describe the survey. In Section 3, we briefly introduce the multiple comparison problem and the decision rules. We then present the hierarchical Bayesian model used to obtain posterior classification probabilities while accounting for the spatial structure via improper multivariate conditionally autoregressive (IMCAR) prior. Results by parasites and by farms are described in Sections 4 and Conclusion and Discussion in Section 5.

sec.title: 2 Data
sec.p: Data come from a cross-sectional study carried out in the Campania Region (southern Italy) which aimed to investigate the spatial distribution of parasitic infections in ovine farms.

A geographical information system (GIS, ArcGIS 8.3, Gauss-Boaga projection Geodetic datum Rome40) was constructed using the administrative boundaries (at provincial and municipal levels) of the region. In addition, as part of the regional project MAPZOO,10 all the sheep farms of the region were geo-referenced. In order to uniformly sample the farms throughout the entire region, a grid with quadrants of 10 × 10 km was overlaid on the region map within the GIS. As a result, the territory of the Campania region was divided in 135 equal cells, the centroid of each cell was identified and the Euclidean distances between the farms and cell centroids were evaluated. Inside each quadrant, the farm closest to the cell centroid and respecting the inclusion criteria of having more than 50 animals was selected. Out of the total 135 quadrants, 121 were investigated. The remaining 14 were wild areas without any farms satisfying inclusion criterion. Fecal samples were collected from 15 adult sheep (>18 months) and 5 youngs (>18 months) on each farm (total number of animals = 2420 sheep).

Fecal samples were pooled at the laboratory in order to obtain four composites over five individual per farm. The FLOTAC technique with a sensitivity of two eggs/g of faeces (EPG) was employed for coprological examinations.11 In the analysis, we used the average over the 4 composites for 16 different parasites.

sec.title: 3.1 Multiple comparisons: general aspects
sec.p:
Let define Iik an indicator for rejecting H0 for the i × k-th test, and R = ∑ik Iik the total number of rejections. Define also rik∈{0,1} the indicator of the unknown true status, rik = 1 denoting the null hypothesis H0. Possible results on all the n = I × K tests are listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Possible results on n hypothesis tests
H0 true (rik = 1) H0 false (rik = 0)
Accept H0 (Iik = 0) True non-discovery False non-discovery n–R
Reject H0 (Iik = 1) False discovery True discovery R

The number of false discoveries (FD) is given by ∑ik (rik × Iik) and the number of false non-discoveries (FND) by ∑ik((1-rik)×(1-Iik)). The false discovery proportion (FDP) is thus ∑ik(rik×Iik)/R, FD diveded by the total number of rejections R, and the false non-discovery proportion (FNP) is ∑ik((1-rik)×(1-Iik))/(n-R), FND divided by the total number of non-rejected hypotheses. Benjamini and Hochberg3 proposed to control the FDR i.e. the expected value of FDP, E(FDP), taking the expectation over repeated experiments. Storey5 introduced the pFDR, which is the FDR conditioning on the occurrence of at least one rejection. The pFDR, a posterior Bayesian probability under certain assumptions, is used to define the q-value, Prob(H0|Y≥Yobs), for a given Y test statistics. Efron12,13 introduced the local FDR, the posterior probability of the null hypothesis conditional of observed vector Y and hyperparameter vector ξ, which is Prob(H0|Y=Yi;Y,ξ)=Prob(ri=1|Y=Yi;Y,ξ)—for simplicity we denote the generic i-th test statistics Yi. Efron followed an empirical Bayesian approach and local FDRs were calculated at some suitable empirical value of ξ. A full Bayes approach will use marginal posterior probabilities Prob(H0|Y=Yi;Y)=Prob(ri=1|Y=Yi;Y).8 We propose a tri-level Bayesian Hierarchical model to obtain fully Bayesian estimates of Prob(ri=1|Y=Yi;Y), which we call posterior classification probabilities.14

sec.title: 3.2 Hierarchical model for posterior classification probabilities
sec.p:
For ease of explanation, we refer to our Veterinary Epidemiology example. We used the square root transformation of fecal eggs count Yik, where I indexed the farms (i = 1, … , 121) and k (k = 1, … , 16) indexed the parasites. The scheme of the hierarchical model is as follows:
Yik| µik,τk ∼ Normal(µik,τk) first level: likelihood
μik=rikμ0ik+(1-rik)μ1ik mixture model (null vs non-null)
µ0ik = 0 Null
µ1ik = αk+ψik non-null
αk ∼ improper uniform
ψi|ψj∈Si ~MVN(ψ¯j∈Si,Σi) second level: prior on model random effects
rik|πik∝Bernoulli(πik) third level: prior for the indicator of the true status (null vs non-null)
πik∝Beta(9,1) hyperprior for the third-level hyperparameter

In the first level of the hierarchy, we specify the likelihood for Yik the transformed eggs count. We assume a Normal density with mean parameter μik and parasite specific precision parameter τk. The mean μik is modeled as a mixture of two components: μ0ik, the expected value under the null hypothesis, and μ1ik, under the alternative. Under the null, we assume a one-point probability mass. The expected value under the alternative is modeled as a linear random effect model with a parasite-specific intercept αk and a Multivariate random term ψik for which we assume an IMCAR structure,15 a generalization of the univariate CAR model.16

That is ψi has a k-dimensional multivariate normal distribution with k-th element of the conditional mean vector given by the average of the neighbouring ψjk’s, j in Si (the set of the neighbouring cell to the i-th one following the queen definition, i.e. cells in the diagonal of the i-th cell are also considered its neighbors) and conditional covariance matrix inversely proportional to the number of neighbours ni, with k-th diagonal element representing the conditional variance of the k-th component of ψ and off-diagonal elements representing the conditional covariance between each pair of the k elements of ψ. It implies that for each k-th parasite, we are assuming that its mean parameter is spatially structured between farms (cells) and within farm (cell) parasite k = l and k = m with l ≠ m are correlated due to unmeasured risk factors. This modeling choice can be viewed as a flexible non-parametric way to take into account hidden large-scale spatially structured confounders.17

In the third level of the hierarchy, we specify the prior distribution on the unknown true status indicator rik as Bernoulli (πik). The posterior of πik is the posterior classification probability, that is the probability to belong to the set of the null hypothesis.6 We assume an exchangeable Beta (9,1) distribution as a priori for πik, that is we a priori put 90% probability on the null. A sensitivity analysis on the choice of the prior can be found in Catelan et al.14

sec.title: 3.3 Posterior probabilities and decision rules
sec.p: Marginalizing the full joint posterior distribution, we obtained posterior classification probabilities πik|Y, posterior inclusion probabilities 1-πik|Y and posterior mean values µik|Y of transformed fecal eggs count. Then, using the posterior quantities of interest, we set the decision rules by which a farm and/or parasite is declared at risk or not.
In the first case, we reject H0 (Iik = 1) when πik|Y the posterior probability to belong to the set of the null is lesser than a predefined cut-off value.
In the second case, we reject H0 (Iik = 1) when the posterior predicted number of fecal egg counts is bigger than a given cut-off value. This threshold is chosen on subject-specific information.
Any given choice of a cut-off value implies different “costs,” which can be measured in terms of absolute number or in term of rate of false discovery and false non-discovery.

Posterior estimates of FD, FN, FDR, and FNR (denoted as fd, fn, fdr, fnr) can be readily obtained from posterior summaries as: fd=sum(πik|Y×Iik)fn=sum(1-πik|Y×(1-Iik)fdr=sum(πik|Y×Iik)/Rfnr=sum((1-πik|Y)×(1-Iik))/(n-R) where Iik is defined as before, either Iik=I(πik|Y<cut-off); Iik=I(μik|Y>cut-off); and R = sum of Iik.

In our analysis, we a priori fixed four different cut-offs for posterior classification probabilities (0.05, 0.10, 0.20, and 0.30) and posterior mean values, which we expressed retro-transforming to fecal eggs count of 250, 50, 10, and 5 EPG.

sec.title: 3.4 Computational details
sec.p: The marginal posterior distributions for the parameters of interest were approximated by Monte Carlo Markov Chain methods (MCMC). We have made use of WinBUGS software (see Reference [18]) in order to perform the MCMC analysis. We have run two independent chains and checks for achieved convergence of the algorithm were performed.19 The algorithm seems to converge after 5000 iterations, however, given that the model is highly parameterized, we decided to run 100,000 and to store for estimation the last 10,000 iterations.

sec.title: 4.1 Spatial distribution of eggs count and random terms
sec.p:
Figure 1 shows the geographical distribution of observed fecal eggs count for the 16 analyzed parasites in Campania Region. The geographical distribution is very different by parasites: some exhibit a strong spatial structure, others are heterogeneous in the region, and some parasites are almost absent in the examined territory. Figure 1.
Spatial distribution of observed fecal egg counts for the 16 selected sheep parasites. Campania Region, Italy, 2004–2005.

Figure 2 reports the distribution of the multivariate clustering term ψi for each of the 16 parasites. For parasites with a high fecal eggs count in a large number of farms (e.g. parasite number 9), the geographical pattern of the random term is close to that shown in Figure 1. On the other hand, parasites with low number of egg counts (e.g. parasites number 6 or 7) have a spatial distribution of the clustering terms which is driven by the correlation structure induced by the IMCAR model. If the model is correctly specified, there is an increase in power and estimation of posterior classification probabilities will take advantage of this correlation structure. Figure 2.
Spatial distribution of clustering random terms for the 16 parasites (see text). Campania Region, Italy, 2004–2005.

sec.title: 4.2 Results by parasites
sec.p:
In Figure 3, we show the box plot of posterior inclusion probabilities (1-πik|Y), the probabilities of the non-null hypothesis, for each of the 16 parasite. For each parasite, we report the marginal posterior distribution over the 121 farms. There is a high heterogeneity among parasites. For some (e.g. parasite 2), inclusion probabilities are close to one for all the investigated farms, indicating a widespread infection, for others (e.g. parasite 7), inclusion probabilities are concentrated around zero, indicating that the infection is very rare and limited to few affected farms. Parasite 1 shows a distribution of posterior probabilities concentrated around the central value of 50%, indicating a strong uncertainty. A large number of parasites has wide distributions of posterior probabilities that range from 0 to 1, indicating that the infection is clustered in some areas of the investigated region. Figure 3.
Posterior inclusion probabilities by 16 parasites (see text). Campania Region, Italy, 2004–2005.

We report for exemplification the results for 2 selected parasites, which represent two different paradigmatic situations. Let us consider Parasite 1 for which 75% of the distribution of observed fecal eggs count is below 14 EPG, 25% has zero EPG (n = 30), and only 3 farms have large counts above 100 EPG. If the decision rule is based on posterior classification probabilities πik |Y and, for example, we fix a cut-off level of 0.05, the number of discoveries (farms declared at high risk) is 7, the fdr is 0.017 and the fd is almost zero (Table 2). On the other hand, using posterior inclusion probabilities (1-πik|Y) with a symmetrical cut-off of 0.95, the number of farm classified not at risk is 114 (121-7), the fnr is 0.499, and the fn is 57. If we use the predicted mean values of EPG for defining our decision rule, and we fix a cut-off of 250 EPG (a value commonly used in parasitological investigations), the number of discoveries is zero (the number of non-discoveries is obviously 121), with 64 false non-discoveries (fnr is 0.527). We have a substantial number of false non-discoveries. Controlling FNR is very difficult in this case due to the relevant number of farms with low but not zero fecal eggs count. Table 2.

Let us now concentrate on parasite 3, which is present in few farms (only 4 have EPG above 20), and 75% of the farms have zero count of EPG. In this case, the decision rules based on posterior probabilities got a better separation in terms of FD and FND (Table 3). Indeed, for all the chosen cut-offs, we have zero fd and almost zero fn. When we base our decision on the posterior mean value of fecal eggs count, we got high number of FND for all the chosen cut-offs. The empirical evidence and decision rule based on posterior probabilities support that farms are clustered with 63 negatives and 58 positives for infection, but this implies that we are actually screening as if a cut-off below 5 EPG be set, which may be questionable in terms of subject-specific knowledge. sec.title: 4.3 Results by farms
sec.p:
For each farm, we evaluate the marginal posterior classification probabilities marginalizing over the 16 parasites. In the star plot (Figure 4) each star represents one of the 121 farms. If posterior inclusion probabilities for all the 16 parasites were found close to one in a farm then the corresponding star plot would have 16 radius with maximal length, since it is proportional to the posterior inclusion probability. It is clear from Figure 4 that no farm is immune to all the parasites and that there are no farm with high prevalence for all parasites. Figure 4.
Star plots of posterior inclusion probabilities by 121 farms (see text). Campania Region, Italy, 2004–2005.

Now look at fd, fn, fdr, and fnr fixing a cut-off value of 0.90 on posterior probabilities. In Figure 5(a), we report fd vs fn and in Figure 5(b) fdr vs fnr. The numbers on the plot represent the ID of the 121 farms. Figure 5.
Profiling farms over parasites: trade-off between fd vs fn (a) and fdr vs fnr (b) (decision rule based on a cutoff of 90% on posterior probabilities, see text). Campania Region, Italy, 2004–2005.

The trade-off between FD and FN have a direct interpretation in terms of cost of erroneous decision (Figure 5(a)). If we look at the number of false non-discoveries (fn, y-axes) we can see that over the 16 parasites screened, no more than 3 are missed by the surveillance system. The number of false discoveries (fd) is almost zero in all the farms. This can be important or not depending on the parasite and subject-specific decision. However, the number is not great so in terms of farms we found a good classification performance.
In terms of fdr vs fnr (Figure 5(b)), we can see that fdr is almost zero for all the farms but more than 10 farms have an fnr higher then 20%.

In Table 4, we report the same information for some selected farms. The first column shows the rank of the farm in terms of fnr. The label “I90” denotes the number of positive parasites choosing a cut-off value of 0.90 on posterior inclusion probabilities. For example, the farm E4 (row shaded in grey in Table 4) which ranks 118° was positive for three parasites using that cut-off. sec.title: 5 Discussion and conclusions
sec.p: We proposed a tri-level Hierarchical Bayesian model to obtain posterior classification probabilities which account for multiple comparisons.

The Campania region was projected into a plane using the standard projection for Italy. The adopted sampling scheme was to select the closest farm to each cell centroid on a regular grid, using Euclidean distances (min 203, median 3502, max 7000 m). In this work, we considered the data as areal data and we referred each farm to the grid cell and consistently we specified an IMCAR model. Several modeling alternatives may be considered: create a neighborhood structure using exact farm centroid distances and a neighborhood cut-off (e.g. Reference [20]); define the data as point-referenced and specify a multivariate spatial model.21 The first proposal may result in areas of different size and the second may be computationally cumbersome. Our choice was to consider the simpler and less-demanding model, not only computationally but also in terms of data and field requirements. The use of exact farm centroids should be considered when the cell area is relatively large, a large part of the land cannot be used for pasturing and farm density is sparse. This could be the case in some part of the region, but in the present study, this affects only two cells—the Neapolitan conurbation and the Vesuvio vulcanic area. We found Geostatistical models valid but computationally more demanding.22

Our model assumed a Normal distribution for the square root transformation of EPG. This could be discussed for the presence of parasites with zero EPG counts in a high number of farms, letting in a potentially skewed distribution. In Biggeri et al.,23 we specified a zero-inflated Poisson model and we compared the two modeling approaches. For the present application, we preferred a simpler Gaussian model for the transformed counts. Alternatives could be the adoption of other count transformations.24,25

Notice that the multivariate spatially correlated specification lead to a borrowing strength of information between parasites in making inference on posterior quantities of interest, which is particularly important when data on a single response are sparse.

A frequentist or empirical Bayes approach to control for multiple testing consists in a post-processing of p values or posterior probabilities. The Bayesian approach described here allows calculation of marginal posterior probabilities and predicted mean values that can be used to build up decision rules. We fixed four decision rules to screen for parasites/farms at high risk and compare the results in terms of FD and FND. Epidemiological Surveillance on parasitic disease usually relies on observed statistics, e.g. fecal eggs count. A formal approach has never been addressed in this field. A trade-off of FD and FND permits to appraise uncertainty and relative advantages of a given decision (see Reference [8] for an application in Genomics). Our approach proved useful for parasitological risk profiling and we show that decision rules can be easily handled.

The goodness-of-fit of a series of plausible hierarchical models was explored in previous work. The model presented here is quite flexible and has a close performance to the simpler two-level IMCAR.26,27

The statistical analysis underlines the cost in term of FND of the usual decision rule based on the fecal eggs count. In the example provided, the reader can see that there is substantial risk of false negatives for some parasites and in some farms. This may suggest to tailor a selective surveillance for them, for example by a second screening round at shorter time interval.

Our model takes advantage of the multivariate spatial structure. This is feasible in the case of an Epidemiological Surveillance over a large scale, like Campania region in the motivating example. Space-time extensions of this approach to rotate sampling schemes are going to be considered.
